pros: Your experience as an employee at UD will completely depend on your unit/department. I have worked for two separate units and my experience has been completely different with each. Stick to the academic side of operations (work for an academic unit or department such as College of Arts and Sciences; Health and Sport Science, etc.) as opposed to the administration side (like Dining Services, Facilities, Parking Services, etc.) and you will likely encounter much friendlier people and a better atmosphere. As a whole, the benefits are great and there are many holidays since it's a Catholic university (15 a year) as well as generous vacation and sick time. The academic side is incredibly supportive of educational goals, so take advantage of free schooling. There is an emphasis on community and family. A really fantastic place to work if you can stick to the academic side of things.
cons: There is little room for financial growth. Everyone gets the same amount of raise each year (generally around 2.5%) regardless of performance. It's also tough to grow professionally if you are on the academic side of operations but don't wish to teach.

review_title: Educational benefits & friendly environmnet, bogged down by beaurocratic blah blah
pros:
Benefits package is good, tuition remission is great especially for family members.. 
The university community is very inclusive and friendly of every equal-opportunity factor (age, race, gender, etc).
cons:
Pay is lower than average for the industry (IT), even with tuition remission benefits figured in to the 'total package'. Great for younger employees and first-time employees, or for parents putting their kids thru college, but not for the in-betweens or post-kid adults.
Beaurocracy of the place is overwhelming sometimes. P.C. rules the day to the extreme and can hamper creativity.
Promotions above mid levels can be slow/non-existant (unless they're "laid off").

review_title: UDRI is a Great Company for Growth
job_title: Machine Learning Research Engineer in Dayton, OH
pros: Growing Rapidly - Very Successful. Positive Work Culture, Professional Growth Opportunities, Engaging and Challenging Work, Well-Integrated with Customers. Truly great people and projects. Benefits package (UD Free Tuition and Low-Premium Health Care) is rock solid.
cons: Like all Defense contractors, project direction can be confusing at time due to multiple requirement/customers. Projects don't always connect with a bigger vision and get shelved. Salary/Bonus compensation aren't always competitive with industry standards.

review_title: University of Dayton Housing and Residence Life
job_title: Student Neighborhood Fellow in Dayton, OH
pros: UD's Catholic and Marianist charism create an environment that is warm and friendly. I felt as if my fellow staff members and my supervisors truly cared about my life, well-being, and future. I enjoyed how people would check in on each other and create dynamic relationships that brightened the day.
cons: I worked specifically in Housing and Residence Life. In situations that required management to take disciplinary action with employees, we often felt as if our own concerns and perspectives were ignored and not given value. Consequences would be handed out without taking into account the intent behind someone's specific actions. Both good and bad intent were treated the same way.

pros: Great boss and co-workers. Amazing chance to be mentored by slightly older employees. The environment was extremely collaborative and helpful. Working in such a young office made it feel very lively.
cons: Restriction of hours to 20 per work week. There were many opportunities to move up post graduation. The pay also wasn't fantastic, but most of the time it did seem to be relative to the work that was required. Upper management was very open to trying new things or ways to go about things.

pros: Location -- UD is in a medium size city with a very reasonable cost of living, good schools, and good transportation,  The university has a beautiful campus with mostly residential students.  Faculty have access to all campus events including plays, sports, music.  Very friendly environment.  An attempt to inculcate the "Catholic, Marianist" charism with an emphasis on community.
cons: In the past few years, UD has gone from being a collegial place where faculty input was welcome and respected, to a university that is run almost entirely like a corporation, where employees (including faculty) have little or no involvement.  Curriculum, working policies, etc. are not almost totally decided by a bureaucratic administration that seems to have forgotten its true mission.

review_title: Adjunct Teaching in the Communication Dept. at UD
pros: The Communication Department at UD has wonderful faculty and company culture. Adjuncts are treated as equal colleagues with full-time faculty and are valued as competent professionals, which is not always the case for part-time college instructors. The leadership is excellent, hours are flexible, and I have a pleasant shared work space in a dedicated office in the department.
cons: Adjunct pay in general is low, though UD is in line with other major Universities in regard to part-time faculty compensation.   This is the only con of the job for me.  My spouse works at UD full time so we don't need to duplicate benefits, which would be the other draw back for some individuals looking at part-time teaching.

review_title: Great opportunity to build career before graduation
pros: UD cares a lot about their students and provides many ways for them to succeed while still in school. One of these ways is through student employment. I always felt encouraged by the staff and was able to build quality relationships with not only the staff but my student co-workers as well. The staff encouraged success with academics by providing leniency and flexibility with work schedules. All while helping students to build skills to use in their future careers
cons: The administration. Some students are working to put themselves through college and putting a cap on hours per week prevents us from doing that. Threatening to fire us if we work too much is absurd.

review_title: Good position to obtain some important skills for certain post-grad careers.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Dayton, OH
pros:
-Work around great colleagues and students
-Can pick up a lot of different skills
-Meet so many people
-Can get pretty busy during rush periods (this is good in certain areas)
cons:
-Hours can be minimal at times (part-time but still)
-Too many managers creates conflicting goals sometimes
-Can be slow at times
-Management can be a little snide at times, especially to other managers.

pros: You are allowed to do own work when you don't have clients. The tutoring space is spacious, so you don't feel cramped when working with students. Students are almost always friendly.
cons: The managers are graduate students and some can be overbearing. Depending on when you are scheduled, you can get stuck with some that are inflexible. Some managers are not understanding of you having to miss shifts if you get sick the last minute or in advance for an interview. It is hard to get people to fill-in your shifts if you need.

review_title: Good way to spend a summer
pros: Really enjoyed my job.  Great way to spend a summer.   I enjoyed the research and people I worked with.   Very flexible schedule; I worked at pools, parks, and on vacations (which I would not have been able to take during a normal internship).
cons: I truly have no complaints.    It depends on the faculty member you work with.  If you like the professor you work with and the research you do, you will enjoy the summer.

review_title: UD provides a welcoming and friendly atmosphere to its employees while continuously improving their research capability.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Scientist in Dayton, OH
pros:
Benefits package
HR
Welcoming atmosphere
Beautiful campus
Principles-first administration
cons:
Pay
Career advancement opportunities for staff
Disconnect (relative) between engineering, sciences, and surrounding resources

job_title: Student Library Assistant in Dayton, OH
pros: Friendly atmosphere, decent pay, great benefits. I especially liked knowing that when i was going into work that despite any gossip everyone was going to treat me with kindness and respect.
cons: not really, good place to work, sometimes with too much gossip, but honestly if you're looking for a foot in the door or just a job with benefits UD is an excellent place to look and I recommend it.

review_title: A great place to work and learn!
pros: The atmosphere on campus is warm and inviting, and everyone I interacted with, from other employees to students, was welcoming and friendly. The people make it a great place to work and to go to school!
cons: Most jobs are for students and are minimum wage. It can be hard to get a job without knowing someone who already works there There doesn't seem to be much room for career growth for jobs as students.

review_title: Like other universities, UD marginalizes its instructors in the Intensive English Program in salary and workload
pros:
I loved the idea of teaching at a university that boasts about teaching for social justice and for Marianist values. 
I have benefited greatly from funding for professional development, including travel to national conferences. The IEP program is supportive of presenting research at the national and international levels.
6 weeks off during the summer
Generous holiday schedule (extra time at Easter and Christmas)
cons: IEP Instructors makes roughly $10,000 less than other UD faculty, even lecturers who teach in the Global Languages Department with similar education. IEP Instructors teach 11-month contracts rather than the 9-month contracts that other UD faculty have. IEP instructors teach 18 contact hours while other UD faculty teach 9 contact hours maximum. IEP instructors teach 5 entire terms in one calendar year, leading to rapid burnout and disengagement from students. It's terribly difficult to build the relationships with students (which is crucial according to our Marianist mission) when the very design of the program inhibits this goal. Over time, there has been increasing distrust between IEP faculty and management that stems from increasing control over course design and assessment. IEP faculty are constantly "asked" to serve on committees without any additional compensation. When these committees are headed by managers, the committee members have little to no control over decision-making. Ultimately, decisions in this program are made by management with little regard for how the decisions affect faculty. Because of this, distrust and resentment continue to grow while the management determines that the problem comes from teachers who just want to complain and need to learn how to be grateful for their jobs. In terms of job promotion, there is no possibility of promotion as an IEP instructor. You are either an instructor or a manager. There are no possibilities for instructors to become Senior Instructors or anything like that. You are just an instructor until you feel like quitting.

review_title: Good resume building experience as a white female student
pros: Many opportunities for students to expand and build upon skills learned in the classroom; supervisors are student academics-friendly; supervisors respect student needs and communicate well with other staff
cons: Not very diverse; corruption in upper management; low wages for hourly workers; extremely low wages for workers employed by companies that UD contracts out for services like maintenance and cleaning

job_title: Undergraduate Music Minister in Dayton, OH
pros:
Good Hands-on Experience.
Flexible Hours for weekdays and weekends.
Good people to work with.
On the job training for music and class required
cons: There are no real cons to this job as a University part time student job. You must apply to be an UGMM and it is quite rewarding. My only complaint is the few hours that are paid.

review_title: A fantastic company to work for, outside of salary.
pros: The work is quite interesting, there are many areas to work in, the people are fantastic, management structure (at least at the Research Institute) is very flat and management is actively working on projects, benefits are the best I have ever seen, they truly care about your family life (great work-life balance)
cons: Salary is low, feast-or-famine as far as work goes (that's the nature of research though)

pros: I was doing what I love among loving co-workers surrounded by art from around the world.
cons: I was expected to do 35-40 hours of work in 20 because "that's all we have in the budget." Furthermore, myself and most of the rest of my department were beholden to two departments; ore headed by a priest who appreciated beautiful art, the other headed by a bean counter priest who guarded the bottom line and wanted all projects completed to please potential donors.

review_title: Good place to be an exec, bad place to be the "little guy"
pros:
The community is strong and you will likely end up working with people who you will like. However much of this bond between employees comes from mutual frustration at the way that employees are treated

The facilities are also quite nice
cons: Part time and student employees get the short stick in terms of wages, being asked to work extra/volunteer hours and are negatively affected by constant shortsighted and moronic decisions made by the heads of departments and programs

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Dayton, OH
pros: Excellent Benefits. Good health care package. Friendly Professors with flexible hours. Low student faculty ratio therefore less grading. Beautiful campus with a lot of resources.
cons: Low pay and engineering TAs do not get tuition remission. Some students are the last minute type and will come knocking a day to submission deadline.

pros:
Good work/life balance
Lots of freedom to do my job as I see fit
Excellent 403(b)/401(a) plan (low fees, generous match)
Very good health insurance options, overall benefit package
Free school for me, almost free undergrad tuition for kids
16 paid holidays, 12 days sick leave, 12-18 days vacation
cons:
Paternity leave policy is garbage (you can use 3 days of sick leave)
Pay is slightly on the low side (maybe 5% below market), but benefits probably make up for that

review_title: Clear focus on Marianist mission & employee happiness
pros: The whole university is geared towards executing and living out the Marianist mission.  Employees live out the mission in their work - especially in interactions with customers or students.
cons: As with many Catholic institutions, pay can be below industry standard.  A new raise structure is being implemented in the Research Institute that will award top performers competitive salaries.

review_title: Many upper administrators are great people but poor managers
pros:
Wonderful people
Lots of collaboration
Dayton is actually a pretty great city - very underrated
Catholic and Marianist values are important to the institution
cons:
Poor leadership - people are promoted because they espouse Catholic and Marianist values, but have horrible management and organizational skills.
Lots of people who have never left UD
Alumni and reputation take priority over current students

job_title: Dining Room Attendant in Dayton, OH
pros: Food allowance, break times, schedule for students is understanding, they provide us with the uniforms, the supervisors get to know you on a personal level.
cons: Too many supervisors which at times can be confusing when one supervisors is asking you to do something and the other is upset at you for doing that.

pros: Students make the workplace nice, since they show more respect to employees than the week managers playing leaders.
cons: Very low pay and a ton of micro managers who move from one job to another because VPs fail to take action when employees complain.  If you are a union employee; plan on management treating you as an outsider since they are not considered part of the UD team.  Sad things have grown so hostile over the past two decades.

job_title: LTC Student Assistant in Dayton, OH
pros: Great understanding of the need to balance studies, while earning decent campus wages. The managers are also excellent and are flexible to work around your needs.
cons: There are too many student employed, meaning you will be scheduled for on average 10 hours/week. Additionally, there can be times when regardless of student events you have going on - you must attend misc meetings.

pros: The people there are very helpful and share insight as to the best ways to complete tasks. The staff was friendly and utilized a great mix or "work" and "play" when it came time for breaks.
cons: The long hours and the distance I had to walk from my car to the building. Also the elevators rarely worked and were constantly trapping people in them.

pros: Getting job experience in college. Gaining experience in customer service is important for almost any career path, and a student job will almost always have that component.
cons: Not all of the available campus jobs are set up in a way that takes into consideration a student's schedule.

pros: Work/school balance very important, campus jobs were very flexible working around class duties (homework, extracurricular activities, etc.)
cons: Near minimum wage pay, but that is to be expected when you're working part-time while studying.

review_title: Worked as a research engineer since 2013
pros:

Fancy equipment for materials analysis

salary is low
Good reputation of UD is well known in OH, but no as well in other states

pros: Upbeat, positive culture. Talented people solving meaningful problems with complex skills.
cons: Contractors follow govt customers and contract money, could end every year. Also, pay is tied to University  and doesn't reflect risk and skill involved in Research Institute side.

pros:
Grading and providing review for algorithm, database, Cyber Forensics and OS classes. 
My work was to help students solve problems when they were learning computer science courses. This helps me to know how to better discuss technical issues with others.
cons: No downsides of this, I am very glad to be a GA for my advisor and this is my pleasure to help him

review_title: Attorney coach of the Undergrad Mock Trial Team
job_title: Attorney Coach of Mock Trial Team in Dayton, OH

cons: None that I can think of.  This is a voluntary position, so no compensation is expected.  The school does pay for lodging at competition events for the coaches.

review_title: Union (red-headed step child) employee in Facilities Management

cons: chaotic management,more Chiefs then Indians situation,no trust of employees,camera's everywhere,major moral issues,job being phased out to solely contracted services.older employees forced out,job descriptions rewritten constantly,after years in same position your suddenly no longer qualified for your job anymore and "axed"

cons: Hard to achieve a good work, school, life balance as there is very little down time. Not much diversity on campus.

pros: I gain a lot of experience related to infectious diseases  like TB HIV/AIDS and also I have knowledge about transition and signs of Malaria. and Malarial Laboratory and quality assurance. And how to manage workload.

pros: Love UD. As an alum I will always value my time there. So much progress on campus.
